Description: Fragment of lid of Attic black-figured pottery Nikosthenic pyxis; interior: glazed streaky black with added red band near perimeter; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of body and hindquarters of lion to left (added white under belly) standing erect on near leg with far leg raised and tail down; at right, Athena, to left (one hand, advanced foot, toe of other foot (all in white); lower part of long foldless skirt and mantle in red); to outside, thin black band above band in red; below, glazed.
Curator's comments: For parallels regarding the subject, compare LIMC V sv Herakles pl. 37, no. 1807. It is possible that the piece belongs to the pyxis 1886,0401.1289. For the shape, see the Nikosthenic pyxis lid, Florence 76931, ABV 229.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B600.15)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 346, no. B429)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0822) (Phase 1)
Lyon 2009 / Nikosthenic Pyxides between Etruria and Greece (p. 179, no. 91)
